Award.AwardTitle: Solar Cell Imaging: A Gateway for Visualization and Learning in STEM Disciplines

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is developing, validating, and disseminating a series of educational modules based on a "tool box" of solar cell imaging techniques with the aim of teaching undergraduates the concepts and methods of core and advanced STEM subjects. These topics include optics; infrared physics, image capture, processing, and analysis; thermography; heat transfer; semiconductor devices and technology; metallography and materials science; statistics and signal processing. By using a battery of imaging techniques to study diverse physical effects in similar-type samples, students are gaining an appreciation of how seemingly unrelated phenomena are connected, and how different measurement techniques can be used to corroborate, complement, or supplement the limitations of other techniques. Data on student learning outcomes are being collected and analyzed to evaluate the effectiveness of the modules.

The project is elevating imaging, both optical and thermal, to a more prominent place in undergraduate education, and is facilitating students' learning core STEM subjects by providing visualization of optical, electrical, mechanical, and thermal effects in semiconductor energy conversion. This works exploits and leverages the advent of low-cost but powerful imaging technology to teach core concepts in science and engineering. This innovative project is preparing students for the ever-expanding, and increasingly important, applications of imaging in quality control, process automation, biomedical fields such as diagnostics imaging, materials science, electronics manufacturing, homeland security, biorecognition, infrastructure inspection, remote sensing, gas detection, and energy efficiency.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Solar cells are a remarkable technology.  A thin sheet or film of semiconductor material can convert a significant fraction (20% or more) of the energy in sunlight to electricity--with no moving parts, no consumption of fuel, no pollution, no noise, and no signficant safety hazards.  Further, the most common solar cells are made out of the second most abundant element on earth: silicon.   As costs have fallen and production has scaled up, photovoltaic solar cells are no longer a fringe technology, but are poised to make a substantial contribution to world energy needs in the next decade.

Students are eager to learn more about solar energy, both for the career prospects and the natural interest in a technology that will be a cornerstone in a sustainable future. Solar energy will help maintain the high standard of living in the US, and provide an avenue for the developing world to improve living conditions without destroying the environment or exhausting finite resouces.

The structure of this reliable source of 'green'  energy perhaps belies the underlying sophisticated science and engineering of solar cells.  Solar cells are a microcosm of the physical sciences, as photovoltaics technology exploits our understanding of  solid-state physics, optics, thin-films, infrared physics, crystallography and materials science, inorganic chemistry, and semiconductor devices.

Still, solar cells are a supremely accessible techology. A solar cell can be held in the hand and connected to a small electrical load such as a cooling fan.  Students see first hand the operation of solid-state energy conversion. Moreover, solar cells prove an effective vehicle for teaching important concepts and topics in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM).  Further, the advent of low-cost  CCD cameras,  infrared thermal cameras,  handheld lasers, LEDs, detectors, and other sensors and instruments provides a means for probing and exploring the properties and features of solar cells.  Solar cells provide an excellent case study for applications of machine vision, thermography, thin-film optics, and image processing and analysis. Our program was based on the premise that solar cell samples, e.g., solar cells measuring a few centimeters on a side and that can be readily purchased on the internet, along with solar cell materials such as monocrystalline and polycrystalline silcon wafers,  thin-film solar cells, various research materials, and nanotechnology solar cells  such as dye-sensitized titanium dioxide solar cells that are made with popular educational kits for students.

The first modules use CCD images to characterize the grain structure of polycrystalline silicon solar cells.  Grain structure is very prominent in silicon and the average grain size and preferred orientation can be analyzed using image processing software.  Images were also used to detect flaws and defects (such as broken grid lines) in solar cells.  Various lighting schemes with LEDs were used to enhance imaging and detection.

Another apect of solar cell relates to characterizing surface roughness. There are optimal surface roughnesses for solar cells with regard to optical properties such as reflection and light trapping, and manufacturability such as related to screen printing of metal contacts.  Further and more generally, surface roughness is an important characteristic of many technologies. Here, students used several techniques to characterize surfaces including atomic force microscopy, optical and scanning electron microscopy, white light interferometry, LED and laser light scattering,  surface profilimetry with a stylus scanner, depth gauge probing, and various image processing methods.  Some of these methods involve relatively expensive instrumentation, albeit often available at many educational institutions, while others use devices costing a few hundred dollars or less.  It is instructive for students to reconcile and collaborate measurements made by different techniques.  Some of the methods are non-contact and rapid, and can be used in production environments.  For instance, after establishing the validity of laser scanning and CCD imaging for solar cell evaluation and surface roughness characterization, students incorporated these techniques into various machine vision inspection methods on conveyor belts and robotic operations.

Thermal imaging of solar cells and modules was used to find "hot spots" and shunts in solar cells.  These activities introduced students to the burgeoning uses of affordable infrared cameras in thermal sciences and engineering. 

A laser scanner was constructed by students using a laser pointer and spare electronic parts.  This device scanned the solar cell measuring localized photocurrents which is revealing of defects and grain boundary effects.  

Cleanliness of solar cells was probed by fluorescence microscopy.  Many organic contaminants can be imaged with low-cost USB handheld fluorescence CCD microscopes as fluorescent residues on surfaces.  This provides a quantitative method to assess contamination and cleaning procedures. 

In summary, there is a rich repertoire of instructive imaging and related methods to explore and analyze solar cells, with high educational value for STEM.  Further, these methods can be more widely applied to machined surfaces, 3d-printed parts and many other areas of technology.
